<s>the returns to be easily reflected by it, for it appears that 
one & the same sort of rays at equal Angles of incidence 
on any thin transparent plate is alternately reflected by 
it & transmitted for many successions according as the 
the thickness of the plate increases in arithmetical progression 
of the numbers 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, &c so that if the first re-
flection (that which makes the first or innermost Rings 
of Colours) be at the thickness 1, the Ray shall be trans-
mitted at the thickness 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, &c & thereby make the 
central spot & Rings of light which appear by transmission; 
& to be reflected at the thickness 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, &c and thereby make 
the Rings which appear by reflection; and this alternate 
reflection & transmission (as I gather by the 2nd observation) 
continues for above an hundred vicissitudes, & by the 
observations in the next Book for many thousands, 
being propagated from one surface of a Glass plate to the 
other tho the thickness of a plate be a quarter of an inch 
or upwards, so that this alternation seems to be propagated 
from any refracting surface to all distances without end 
or limitation. This alternate reflection & refraction depends 
on both surfaces of every thin plate, because it depends on 
their distance, for if either surface of a thin plate of Mus-
covy glass (Talk) be wetted, the colours caused by the alter-
nate reflection & transmission grow faint, therefore it depends 
on them both. it is therefore performed at the second sur-
face, for if it were performed at the first surface before 
the rays arrive at the second it would not depend 
on the second. it is influenced by some action or dis-
position propagated from the first to the second, because 
otherwise at the second it would not depend on the first. 
& this action or disposition, in its propagation intermits 
& returns by equal intervals, because in all its progress 
it inclines the Ray at one distance from the first surface 
to be reflected, by the second, at another distance from 
it to be transmitted by it, & that by equal intervals for 
innumerable vicissitudes. and because it is disposed to 
reflection at the distances 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, &c to transmission at 
the distances 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, &c (for its transmission through
